areaDesc.3: Good Transportation
areaDesc.4: Congested area of mixed population- very small houses of small value
areaDesc.14: Many boarded up houses in this section- general mixture of population- low class whites- Italians- negroes- Very narrow streets. Woodland Avenue principally business.

areaDesc.3: Suburban atmosphere
areaDesc.4: A very poor section of obsolete houses in poor condition.
areaDesc.14: Has not spread out for sometime, but the poor neighborhood is affecting values in adjacent area.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation - desirable residential area of good character.
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: Many residents of Elkin Park commute to New York City.

areaDesc.3: Desirable section of good character, bus and train transportation.
areaDesc.4: None except some spotty streets

areaDesc.3: Quiet suburban developments- fairly desirable country homes of modest character
areaDesc.4: Transportation to Bustleton is fair-to Somerton good.
areaDesc.14: Somerton is about 15-16 miles from center of city. Sections are desirable to people interested in country homes

areaDesc.3: Direct rail transportation- Homogeneous development of desirable residential area.
areaDesc.4: No
areaDesc.14: Property around R.R. station not quite as high grade. Singles average $20,000, Twins average $10,000. High grade area recently developed. Not quite as accessible as west Germantown section.
Very sparsely settled section because of its distance from the center of the city, expected to take its general character from C-12 immediately adjacent.

areaDesc.3: Industrial employment nearby- fair residential area- elevated and subway transportation.
areaDesc.4: Textile industry in section is practically shut down.
areaDesc.14: Principally a mill section in eastern end. Front St. is partially business. Cheaper rentals in southern eastern end. Philoo employs a large payroll here. Cuneo Press, Heinz, Crown Cork & Seal (Sub. of American Can) have new plants in the section. A third grade yellow section.
Sparsely settled area whose immediate development questionable but because of its location will undoubtedly take its character from Ashburner.

areaDesc.3: nominal
areaDesc.4: Some colored in section.

areaDesc.3: Transportation is good-fairly desirable medium class residential.
areaDesc.4: No sewers in greater portion of section.
areaDesc.14: Section is very spotty, not restricted as to type. Property is owned by population of German descent making section more desirable. A fair second grade section.

areaDesc.3: Not known at present
areaDesc.14: Two story houses in the field under $10,000.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- train and bus- fairly desirable residential section.
areaDesc.4: Surface water in upper end of section.
areaDesc.14: Section has been static, but is expected to improve. No sewers in the section, although plans are under way to eliminate cesspools.

areaDesc.3: Train service
areaDesc.4: Mixture of population of poor class.
areaDesc.14: Italians of foreign born predominate. Section is very spotty with a general mixture of all types of houses.

areaDesc.2: Same as D-2 except further away from center of city.

areaDesc.3: Suburban development - fair transportation.
areaDesc.4: Mixture of nondescript houses. No sewers- streets unimproved.
areaDesc.14: Unrestricted section of nondescript development. River front properties are not good housing. Undesirable people.

areaDesc.3: Close to better section. Direct transportation to center of city.
areaDesc.4: Concentration of Italian. Neighborhood is going down.
areaDesc.14: Italian section of West Philadelphia. Speculative prices prevail. Spreading out to north threatening values in B-1 section. Negro encroachment from south and east.

areaDesc.3: Nothing
areaDesc.4: No sewers- undesirable negro section of very poor property. Flood hazard- Vandalism. 8 feet below river level
areaDesc.14: Considered the worst section in Philadelphia. During 1933-1934 rentals were not collected in lieu of upkeep of property; in some cases tenants were paid to stay. Speculators are not operating in this area.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- close to industry
areaDesc.4: Concentration of undesirables. Low class whites and negro

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- fairly desirable residential section of homes in demand
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: Influx of Jewish has discounted values- moved in during last five years. Well developed section originally- good construction. Better grade of property south of Baltimore.

areaDesc.3: Good Transportation- fairly modern homes- close to industrial employment
areaDesc.4: Surrounded by poorer class sections
areaDesc.14: Portions was government built during war. Some industry in this section,

areaDesc.3: Close to town- Good transportation
areaDesc.4: Heavy obsolescence- infiltration of boarding houses- converted dwellings. Many very large out of style houses of questionable value. Threatened with negro encroachment.
areaDesc.14: Houses between 51st Street and 59th Street on Florence & Warrington Avenue were built and are settling badly. Infiltration of Jewish into area have depressed values. No demand for large houses in this section. Houses being converted into apartments. Baltimore Avenue is largely business as well as 40th, 52nd, 56th and 60th Streets.

areaDesc.3: Direct transportation to center of city. Fairly desirable residential section-
areaDesc.4: Changing neighborhood- Section may be expected to undergo a transition period in the next five years. Converted houses along Walnut.

6.d: Fair- Good on Osage Ave and Cobbs Creek

areaDesc.14: Section on Osage Ave. between 46th and 50th is very good. Infiltration of Jewish, Polish and Italian. Section around Cobbs Creek below Catherine St. in better than balance of the section- values $9000-$15,000 in this section and Osage Avenue section mentioned above. Section has passed its peak, but retains considerable value. Pine St. 5000 block is old 3 story rows. 52nd, 56th and 60th are already given over to business

areaDesc.3: Close to center of city- good transportation
areaDesc.4: Heavy obsolescence of property- concentration of Negroes and Italians.
areaDesc.14: Section is very spotty- still has some of original owners- some streets are better than indicated but influenced by down trend entire area. 40th, 52nd, 56th, 60th and all of Market Street is predominantly business. Elevated runs out Market St.

areaDesc.3: Restricted above Lansdowne Avenue & Haverford Avenue. Very desirable second class neighborhood. Good transportation.
areaDesc.4: None, except possible encroachment from Section C-1.
areaDesc.14: Majority of houses do not have garage. Homogeneous character of population. Lancaster Avenue is largely business- also Lansdowne Avenue around 60th. Jewish have overflowed into this section from B18.

areaDesc.3: Restricted- close to park- desirable residential section- location well protected against encroachment.
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: Lower part of section is threatened with Italian expansion- low grade green. Section is a bit spotty, but is definitely first grade. Minimum of traffic in this area, except on Lancaster Avenue and 63rd St., which is largely business.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- near employment- subway transportation to Snyder Avenue.
areaDesc.4: Heavy obsolescence.
areaDesc.14: Small streets principally 2 story rows. Newer houses are at extreme southern end. Section east of Broad Street is considered fairly desirable. New houses sold readily but buyers are from this section and not of high calibre.

areaDesc.3: Close to City Avenue transportation- close to park and open country- restricted section- direct roads to downtown section.
areaDesc.4: Trolley transportation lacking.
areaDesc.14: Southern part of section is not quite as high grade. Twins are principally in northern section above Woodbine and Wynfield Avenues. Predominately Jewish for many years, except in northern part above Wynfield Ave.

areaDesc.3: Desirable residential section of better homes on larger lots. Good schools, transportation.
areaDesc.4: None, except age of property which does not seem to effect general desirability.
areaDesc.14: Mostly in Lower Merion Township-low taxes, although a good portion of the section is of considerable age, the entire area is considered the most desirable residential section of Philadelphia. Many large estates are mixed in the area and values on such are very high. Sections of the area are somewhat spotty, but the character of the entire section is extremely good.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- low tax rate- desirable residential section.
areaDesc.4: Older property.
areaDesc.14: The oldest development on the "main line".

areaDesc.3: Church influence in the section is holding population and tending to improve class of inhabitants. Several Catholic schools.
areaDesc.4: Some colored between Manayunk on East, Cotton on South, Terrace on West and Monastery Avenue on North. Negroes on Dupont between Manayunk & Mitchell Avenues.
areaDesc.14: Old houses are being remodled and new and modern improvements installed- population has refused to move from the district. Foreign born is definitely improving. Graded 4th grade because of age of property. Section is very unusual. Mills in section now running to capacity.

areaDesc.3: Stability of inhabitants in point of staying in the section.
areaDesc.4: Trolley & subway fare in 13 cents to center of city.
areaDesc.14: Prices increased only in past 6 months. Section is expected to retain desirability.

areaDesc.3: Continuing to be developed as desirable section.
areaDesc.4: No- transportation only fair
areaDesc.14: Rentals have not been increased in this section.
Similar in character to Section E-6 but may develop largely of less expensive houses.
Most of the ground in this section is controlled by the Houston Estate. Development will be quite high grade but generally speaking people are not anxious to move to this particular area.

areaDesc.3: Very high grade section.
areaDesc.4: Only fair transportation.
areaDesc.14: Houses west of School House Lane are very large estates. No ground being sold for building. Some old houses have been remodeled.

areaDesc.3: Fair section.
areaDesc.4: Very old houses- decadence of industry.

6.a: 2 & 3 sty. row- some singles on small streets

areaDesc.14: Section is spotty- some fairly good houses. Business is very poor in the section. One of the oldest developments of Philadelphia. Community known as "Fishtown".

areaDesc.3: Good transportation, particularly eastern part, -Near to industrial plants of major consequence to entire Philadelphia area.
areaDesc.4: Nominal
areaDesc.14: Concentration of industry - Section held up well during depression - good demand from good class of residents - Industry will diversified - Considered good section for third grade.

areaDesc.3: Desirable residential section- fair transportation
areaDesc.4: None

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- close to commercial and industrial area.
areaDesc.4: Negro encroachment- heavy obsolescence.
areaDesc.14: No great demand for property in this section at any time. Many negro families doubled up. Section has been slowly deteriorating for years. Italians are slowly driving negroes out. Small streets are principally 2 story rows. Considerable industry and small business in the section.

areaDesc.3: Germantown section- good R.R. transportation
areaDesc.4: Negro encroachment- some Italian on Mt. Pleasant Avenue. Influx of less desirable element.

6.a: 2 story tows- twins- single- some three story rows

areaDesc.14: A very spotty section of many type houses with varying population- one of the oldest developments of Philadelphia. Germantown is practically all business up to Haines Ave.

areaDesc.3: Heavy obsolescence of property- crowded area of low areas population.
areaDesc.14: Section is blighted and demolition is recommended- originally housed mill workers.

areaDesc.2: Same as D-4 except solid negro of good character.
same as D-4 except solid negro and Italian of fair character
same as D-4 except solid negro and Italian of fair character

areaDesc.3: New Industry- Good transportation.
areaDesc.4: Heavy concentration of negro- properties in poor condition.
areaDesc.14: Better class negro in this section. Conversion of 3 story houses in here. Close to Gratz High School. Close to good industrial section.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- fairly desirable residential section- near large employers along Erie Avenue- large park in section.
areaDesc.4: Nominal.
areaDesc.14: Broad Street is business. Italian encroachment is slow from the south.

areaDesc.3: Good shopping area on Lehigh Avenue and Germantown Avenue. Fairly close to commercial area- good transportation.
areaDesc.4: Obsolescence- some negro- some foreign.
areaDesc.14: Front Street is principally business. Many industrial plants in the section. Broad Street and Germantown Avenue are principally business. Some rents have been increased in recent years, but no blanket increases have been instituted. Vacancies are being increased 10% where they warrant it. A fair 4th grade section.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- close to business and industry- schools are ample.
areaDesc.4: Heavy obsolescence- concentration of negro- many condemned properties- some vandalism.
areaDesc.14: Broad Street is principally business. Only room for building is on property vacated by demolition. Some houses in the section are being held for sale- high vacancy predicated on houses unfit for use. Northern end of section is better. Section is very spotty with colored and white mixed streets. Foreclosures were heavy in this section. A poor 4th grade section.

areaDesc.3: Close to business- good transportation- schools are ample.
areaDesc.4: Heavy obsolescence- concentration of foreigners and some negro.
areaDesc.14: Some factories in the section. Predominance of lower class Jewish. Polish, Lithuanian, Slavs- general mixture of foreign. 40% 3 sty., 60% 2 sty. Market was lacking in 1933-35. Germantown Avenue, Girard Avenue predominantly business. A poor 4th grade section.

areaDesc.3: Nominal- some industry along river.
areaDesc.4: Sewage disposal plant in section- disagreeable odor.
areaDesc.14: Section is spotty- some fair streets. Richmond Street is practically all business. Employment situation has not permitted rental increases.

areaDesc.3: Elevated transportation- good business section on Frankford and Kensington Avenues.
areaDesc.4: Old section.
areaDesc.14: Many textile mills are located here. Industry is somewhat stagnant in the area at present. Section is spotty with some properties in fairly good condition.

areaDesc.3: Very good transportation- near employment. Modern houses- near parks.
areaDesc.4: Shifting type of population.
areaDesc.14: A heavy shifting of occupants- principally industrial workers. Industrial workers in action in constant turmoil. A modest second grade section.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- near employment- cheap rentals
areaDesc.4: Heavy obsolesence- Property in rundown condition- General mixture of population.
areaDesc.14: Frankford Ave. is all commercial. Considerable industry at lower end. Foreigners concentrated west of Frankford Avenue. Some 3 story rows on main streets. Many old owners in the section.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- Industrial plants along river, employs large payrolls.
areaDesc.4: Obsolescence is marked east of Forresdale Avenue.
areaDesc.14: Section West of Frankford Ave. between Orthodox & Cheltenham Ave. and east of Oxford Ave. is of better character and populated by better grade people with values and rentals slightly higher than the balance of the section.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- desirable residential area of good people. Good schools (grade)
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: Tyson Street frontage is good. A fair second grade section.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- fairly modern dwellings. City Park- desirable populace
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: considerable new building to go in here.

areaDesc.3: Fairly new section of good character-good transportation-desirable population. Diversified employment of populace.
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: new houses up to $6500 New construction in 1937 is well ahead of 1936. A good second grade section.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- near park
areaDesc.4: Negro section in center of section.

6.d: fair to poor along R.R. trails

areaDesc.14: Italian & negro located along R.R. tracks. Northern part of section not as well built up. Population has been located here for sometime. Negro concentration is affecting values along Welsh Road from Dittman Avenue to Frankford.

areaDesc.3: Boulevard frontage- restricted to twins or singles.
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: New Houses range $8000-$15,000. Very desirable residential neighborhood. A good second grade section.

areaDesc.3: Near Sears Roebuck Retail & Wholesale Store
areaDesc.4: Transportation is poor- no RR's. 10 cents bus fare to City.
areaDesc.14: Wider streets bring better rentals on houses. Rental shortage is reason for high occupancy.
Sparksely settled area with street lay-outs. In view of the limited territory, the section appears to be the next for volumn building of two story dwellings to sell under 10,000 dollars.

areaDesc.3: Close to business- good transportation- subway, busses, trolley.
areaDesc.4: Negro concentration- heavy absolescence.

12.a: None except on Corinthian Ave. section

areaDesc.14: The section between Corinthian Avenue and 22nd Street from Poplar to Brown was built 15 yrs. ago- values range up to $4,000. rents around $35-45.- Considerable business scattered through this section on main streets. Broad Street is all business.

areaDesc.3: Near Park- close to business- good transportation- better 4th grade section.
areaDesc.4: Heavy obsolescence- large properties.
areaDesc.14: Concentration of Jewish in Northern part- Germans in Southern part- Heavy speculation in this section in 1928-1929,- Strawberry Mansion section- heavy foreclosures- 29th Street is not in good condition for renting.

areaDesc.3: Near commercial area- High class inhabitants-
areaDesc.4: Encroachment of undesirable element from South.
areaDesc.14: Good many apartments of high calibre located here. Highest type residential section in town- many occupants maintaining homes here for occupancy during Season.

areaDesc.3: Broad St. Subway to Snyder- Girard Estate in center of section is holding up values around it.
areaDesc.4: Heavy obsolescence.
areaDesc.14: 2 story rows principally on small side streets and southern end. New construction is up to $6,000. Girard estate is between 18th & 21st from Porter to Passyunk Ave. and is of better grade.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- fairly modern houses
areaDesc.4: Houses are being allowed to depreciate.
areaDesc.14: Section is principally Jewish- Depreciation will be slowed down by good transportation. A fair second grade section, but future is questionable.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation- very desirable residential section- well restricted- wooded section
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: German American population- Broad St. properties are not typical of section as a whole. Section is very desirable, but danger of Jewish encroachment is imminent. A fair first grade section.

areaDesc.3: Desirable industrial section- good transportation. Thrifty class of populace- 2 perks in section.
areaDesc.4: No
areaDesc.14: Most of building in eastern end. High type inhabitants. A fair first grade section.

areaDesc.3: Fairly desirable residential section- although somewhat old. Good transportation.
areaDesc.4: Grade schools in Chew Avenue section have about 15% negro children. Many of the streets are very spotty- some backing up to poorer property.
areaDesc.14: Property on Lincoln Drive in quits high grade but does not warrant a 1st grade rating- values range up to $20,000. Western part of the section below R.R. has larger houses. Twins showed greater shrinkage than singles. There appears to be little danger of the less desirable element encroaching from yellow and red sections.

areaDesc.3: High- wooded section in part- desirable residential section - fairly good transportation.
areaDesc.4: Some unimproved streets- no sewers.

areaDesc.3: The finest residential section in the city. Very good schools- Near parks- electrified train transportation.
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: Shifting of population. People moving further out. Southern end of section has the smaller houses. Buyers still looking for bargains. Practically all available land is held at $20,000 an acre. Direct roads to center of city. Many large estates in this section.

areaDesc.3: Fair transportation
areaDesc.4: None
areaDesc.14: New houses in the section predominate. A good second grade section. Section has been built principally in past five years. The entire area is operation building. Building is moving northeast. Considerable room for expansion. The most active building section in city about 450 units being buily in first months of 1937.

15.1: in first four months of 1937. H.B. Wilson

areaDesc.2: High grade negro-more land around houses-good transportation
areaDesc.3: obsolescence
Sewers- good transportation- good schools- highly desirable residential section- high elevation.
areaDesc.4: Almost solidly build- no room for expansion.
areaDesc.14: Section between Cliveden and Germantown- Willow Grove Turnpike and Oakdale & Mt. Carmel Ave. is very good.

areaDesc.3: Highly desirable, well restricted residential area.
areaDesc.4: No sewers.
areaDesc.14: $15,000-25,000 houses predominate

areaDesc.3: Desirable residential section
areaDesc.4: No sewers- removed from R.R. but near trolley
areaDesc.14: Need underdraining throughout

areaDesc.2: Section is the same as C-2 but is further out from center of city.
